Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Ecology and Evolutionary Biology of Changing Environments: Integrating from Genomes to Biomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Kansas State University, located in Manhattan, KS, will support the training of 9 students in a 10-week program during the summers of 2015-2017. The program is hosted by the Division of Biology, Konza Prairie Biological Station, and the Ecological Genomics Institute (EGI). The program focuses on mechanistic and integrative research in ecology and evolutionary biology, with a theme of ecology and evolutionary biology in changing environments. Program activities include: i) independent research projects that will train students in experimental techniques and design, ii) a seminar on integrative analysis in ecology and evolutionary biology, iii) comprehensive ethics training, iv) professional development and research skills workshops, v) field trips to field sites, biological collections, and genomic facilities, and vi) training in oral communication of students' research results. Participants will have access to an extensive range of facilities and equipment for ecological, evolutionary, and genomic research. Faculty mentors are world leaders in integrative ecological and evolutionary research. Synergy among the REU, EGI, and Konza will provide participants exposure to new and ongoing experiments at Kansas State University. Recruitment and participant selection will focus on the identification of students with outstanding research potential. The program will target students attending institutions without significant undergraduate research opportunities (e.g., primarily undergraduate institutions, community colleges, and tribal colleges). However, all students with outstanding research potential should apply.

It is anticipated that a total of 27 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, analyzed, and communicated. Many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences, and some will publish the results in peer-reviewed journals.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of program. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting www.ksu.edu/reu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Morgan) or co-PI (Dr. Snyder) at biologyreu@ksu.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the grant entitled "REU Site: Undergraduate Research in the Ecology and Evolution of Changing Environments: Mechanisms to Responses" was to create opportunities for independent research in ecology and evolutionary biology by undergraduate students during a 10-week summer program at Kansas State University. The training program is hosted by a collaboration between The Division of Biology, The Konza Praire Long Term Ecological Research Site, and The Ecological Genomics Institute at Kansas State University.  During the program we provided a foundation in mechanistic research training in modern ecological and evolutionary research question for three cohorts of undergraduate students (summers of 2015, 2016, and 2017), and additional students were supported in the summers of 2018 and 2019. The summer students gained practical research skills in molecular techniques, field methods, and experimental design by conducting independent projects under the guidance of experienced research scientists. Mentors benefited through opportunities to direct summer projects with enthusiastic undergraduates who are seeking specialized training in new research areas. Other activities of the grant included professional development opportunities, on site field activities, and training in public speaking. Students were selected for the program from universities across the country, with an emphasis on selecting students with great research potential and selecting students from universities that do not have research opportunities for undergraduates.  All students were supported with a generous research stipend, a travel and housing allowance, and additional funds to offset the cost of conducting their independent research.  All students presented their research twice during the summer; first during in a fast-paced short talk (4 minutes and 4 slides) format and then during a fifteen minute meeting talk during the final symposium. Students also received training in science communication, developed hands-on activities to engage public audiences, and participated in outreach events at Sunset Zoo in Manhattan, KS. Currently, the majority of the student participants are either completing their undergraduate degrees at their home institutions or they have enrolled in diverse STEM graduate programs around the country.  Some students and mentors have also presented their work at national and international conferences and completed manuscripts reporting their research findings. A running list of these publications associated with this REU site can be found at ksu.edu/reu.
